title: undefeated dean sutherland ready to deliver wbc title glory in aberdeen ring return
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. title: scotland autumn series 2021 four changes for the springboks as matt scott returns after four year gap
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. title: scotland autumn series 2021 three key points
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. title: your pictures october 22 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowThis week we feature a series of photographs by Ardrishaig resident James Bowe.Taken on Friday October  during an early morning walk to Cairnbaan, James captured the scene as the sun rose on a beautul day after a spell of rain. The mist rising from the canal makes for a tranquil, slightly eerie autumnal atmosphere.PICS:no_aYourPictures_JamesBoweno_aYourPictures_JamesBoweno_aYourPictures_JamesBoweno_aYourPictures_JamesBoweno_aYourPictures_JamesBowe

title: argyllshire advertiser leader column november 5 2021
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowCaring for the carersThroughout the hardships and challenges of the pandemic, carers have become valued members of families who could barely have survived without them.Providing care for a person in their own home can be le-changing, offering them safety, independence and companionship.There can be few more vital roles to be played in society but are these invaluable people not themselves being supported Caring for the carers by investing in their teams, their working conditions and their pay must be the first priority of the mooted National Care Service, and in the meantime urgent action is needed to attract and retain staff in these crucial roles.When somebody chooses to train for this dficult, but hugely rewarding, career they should feel safe in the knowledge that they will be supported, paid a good wage and not be forced by shortages to offer anything other than the high quality, professional service they so badly want to deliver.RemembranceFor a hundred years communities across the UK have come together to honour all who have lost their lives in wars and military campaigns.These precious acts of remembrance were curtailed last year due to Covid restrictions, so perhaps this year it is more important than ever to head out to churches and cenotaphs all around our community, and together we will remember them.

title: your pictures november 12 2021
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIt#s a special photograph this week for our weekly Your Pictures feature.The fantastic image was sent to us by regular contributor Aileen Gillies, now a photographer with a growing reputation and wide range of calendars to her credit.Aileen sent us this photograph of the sunset at Arduaine, taken on Tuesday November . She also mentioned that this was her #birthday sunset#.So, it might be a few days late, but happy birthday Aileen!

title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: peeblesshire-woman-ran-marathon-memory-beautiful-mum
story: A BORDERS woman completed the London Marathon in memory of her "beautul mum" who passed away following a battle with cancer.Fiona Kennedy, from Peebles, ran her first marathon in  to mark her mother completing  years of treatment for soft tissue cancer and to raise money for Sarcoma UK ndash the charity which had supported her mum throughout her treatment.After completing the Edinburgh race in May  and raising pound,, Fionas mum passed away at the age of  in September ."Mumrsquos ethos meant that she took the years of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and drug trials in her stride," said Fiona. "She continued to travel, play an active part in her grandchildrenrsquos lives and was a much-loved we, mum, sister, and aunt.":Feast of live rugby available for fans in the Borders this weekendAlthough shed sworn to never run again, Fiona, her aunt, uncle and cousins agreed to run a marathon in her mums memory.The family promptly signed up to run the London Marathon  for Sarcoma UK.However, the coronavirus pandemic meant last years marathon was postponed.But despite lockdown, Fiona continued to train for when the marathon was rearranged for October this year.:Man threatened to kill his partner during a bust-up in the Borders"I swore I would never run again after Edinburgh and I crossed the line in London two years later having raised a further pound, for Sarcoma UK," said Fiona."I have been out running in my finishers t-shirt twice since completing London, and I have felt a real sense of accomplishment pounding the pavements in that prestigious t-shirt."Crossing the finish line was a huge sense of relief."My cousin Lucy and I crossed it together hand in hand and promptly burst into tears."The sense of achievement was felt immediately, not least because the staff, marshals and volunteers were amazing in their support and care."The congratulations came from runners, supports and strangers..remove"Mum wasnrsquot at the finish line in London but Irsquom sure she would have been amazed and proud in equal measures.":Photo Gallery: Some of the best Halloween costumes from across the BordersFiona is now looking forward to ing to sports she enjoys, but can also see herself joining in park runs.She said: "I am looking forward to ing to other forms of exercise that I love, but I do see myself factoring in the odd Parkrun to tick my legs over."In terms of fundraising ndash I will have a lelong affiliation with Sarcoma UK."Mum wanted to do more in terms of contributing to research, raising awareness and rising funds, and this is a duty I have inherited."I will continue to look for ways to support the charity I have such fondness for."

title: scott-brash-statue-plans-monument-add-new-dimension
story: THE Olympic legacy of Scott Brash, which was honoured with the erection of a statue, could soon be illuminated with a golden glow.The showjumper landed back in Peebles to unveil the lesize sculpture in recognition of his gold medal back in .The tribute to one of the regionrsquos greatest ever sportsmen was warmly welcomed by the community, and is a spectacular vision on entry to the town from Edinburgh Road.The project was the brainwave of voluntary group Bonnie Peebles, which commissioned the sculpture, which artist Kevin Paxon designed and created from recycled horseshoes.Now, community leaders would like to highlight his golden glory further and hope to work with Bonnie Peebles to clear the final hurdle in this project.During a meeting of Peebles Community Council, members discussed installing lighting at the monument. It was suggested that solar-powered lights would be the most cost-effective option.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler said an application to fund the lighting could be submitted to the Peebles Parking Fees Fund.Chairman Les Turnbull said: ldquoThe Scott Brash monument is a wonderfully impressive artwork at the gateway to the town.ldquoTo have it lit would add another dimension for us all to enjoy, particularly as the nights draw in.

title: scotland-v-australia-channel-scotland-rugby-game
story: Scotlandwill play Australia in their second match of the rugby autumn series this weekend at Murrayfield.Last week the team played against Tonga in front of a home crowd, winning - in an impressive match.Now turning their attention to Australia, the odds look slightly tipped in Scotlands favour, having won the last two matches against the team.With the fansbehind them once again, they will look to repeat last Saturdays triumphant performance as they go against the Aussies for the first time since .As rugby enthusiasts once again fill up the Edinburgh stadium, heres how you can watch at home...Kick-off time for Scotland v Australia match this weekend The Scotland v Australia match will take place at Murrayfield on Sunday November  at .pm.It is the teams second match in the autumn series, which will take place throughout November.What channel isScotland v Australiaand how to watch live Amazon Prime hasthe broadcast rights for the autumn international series in the UK.You will need a membership to tune in, butyou dont already have one you can sign up to a -day free trial.If you dont want to continue your trial after the -days however, you will need to remember to cancel your subscription.When is Scotlands next match in autumn series Here is Scotlands schedule for the autumn series:Scotland v Australia: Sunday November  at .pmScotland v South Africa: Saturday November  at pmScotland v Japan: Saturday November  at pmWhats the Scotland team line-up Stuart HoggDarcy Graham, Chris Harris, Sam Johnson, Duhan van der Merwe Finn Russell, Ali Price Pierre Schoeman, George Turner, Zander Fagerson, Sam Skinner, Grant Gilchrist, Jamie Ritchie, Hamish Watson, Matt Fagerson.Replacements:Ewan Ashman, Jamie Bhatti, Oli Kebble, Jamie Hodgson, Josh Bayliss, George Horne, Adam Hastings, Kyle Steyn.

title: scots-women-take-japan-dam-health-stadium-sunday
story: BORDERS trio Lana Skeldon, Lisa Thomson and Chloe Rollie have been named in Scotland Women Head Coach Bryan Eassonrsquos -player squad for the upcoming Autumn Test against Japan at the DAM Health Stadiumndash live on BBC ALBA.If they play Skeldon will collect her th cap, Thomson will pick up her th cap Rollie will get her th cap.Easson said: ldquoThe upcoming Autumn Test against Japan is a great opportunity for us to learn from our experience in the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers.ldquoJapan have recently qualied for the Rugby World Cup as the highest ranked team in the Asia qualication process so this will be an ideal test for us as it exposes us to a dferent opponent and playing style ahead of our final qualication tournament next year."The players are also excited to run out in front of a home crowd for the first time since , especially as theyve played mostly behind closed doors for the past  months. Weve all hugely missed having crowds so itll be fantastic to have supporters along at the DAM Health Stadium to cheer the players on."Scotlandrsquos last encounter against the Brave Blossoms was in November , which was also the last match they played in front of a home crowd, with Japan taking the spoils that day with a - win.Eassonrsquos squad recently kept their World Cup ambitions in sight following two back-to-back wins against Spain and Ireland during the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers in Parma.The sidersquos recent success has also seen them rise to an all-time high of ninth in the Womenrsquos World Rugby rankings.Forwards: Leah Bartlett , Christine Belisle , Sarah Bonar , Lisa Cockburn , Evie Gallagher , Jade Konkel , Rachel Malcolm , Rachel McLachlan , Louise McMillan , Lyndsay OrsquoDonnell , Lana Skeldon , Emma Wassell , Molly Wright , Anne Young .removeBacks: Shona Campbell , Megan Gaffney , Sarah Law , Rhona Lloyd , Jenny Maxwell , Holly McIntyre , Helen Nelson , Chloe Rollie , Hannah Smith , Meryl Smith , Lisa ThomsonEvie Wills Tickets for Scotland Women v Japan Women are on sale via the SRU website.Kids for pound tickets are available with a paying adult, at pound, and Us go for pound.

title: exciting-competition-young-artists-borders
story: BUDDING young artists in the Borders will have the chance to reimagine the facade of Kelso Town Hall.The best designs will be projected onto the building, for two spectacular nights in February between Saturday th and Saturday th, alongside artwork from Borders Art Fair participating artists.A selection of the designs will also be exhibited at the Borders Art Fair in March.This competition is open to all young people, up to, and including, the age of , who live or, go to school in, the Scottish Borders.There will be prizes for the best entries, according to age groups: under s, -s and  years and over.Digital designs should be sent to info@bordersartfairDesigns on paper can be posted to Border Arts Development, Kirkmains Farm, Jedburgh TD TP or scanned and emailed to info@bordersartfair.Moving image designs should be no longer than  secondsPlease include your name, age, address, email address or phone numberApplicants under  must get consent from their parent or legalbefore entering the competition. This competition is free to enter and no purchase is necessaryBorder Arts Development C.I.C. must receive entries by .pm on Monday th December .A template is available as a starting point for and can be downloaded via https:www.bordersartfair

title: 6-points-covid-scotland-update-today
story: John Swinney stood in for Nicola Sturgeon today to give an update on the state of Covid in Scotland to Parliament.The First Minister was absent from Parliament again this week as she continued with COP hosting duties, with the second week of the climate summit well under way.Last weekhealth secretary Humza Yousaf echoed concerns raised by the First Minister in a previous update regarding the rising numbers of hospitalisations with Covid, which reflected the viruss prevalence among the older population.Warnings were issued before COP suggesting that cases could surge after the summit due to the influx of people to the city.However, the Scottish government has repeatedly confirmed it is doing everything it can to mitigate the chances of a rise in infection rate.Following another Covid statement, heres what we learned from todays announcement.... Cases still hovering around , markA further , cases of Covid were recorded over the past  hours in Scotland,meaning cases continue to hover around the , mark.Cases have recently plateaued around this figure following a decline after a surge in the summer due to the easing of restrictions..  million Covid boosters and third vaccinesThe deputy first minister confirmed that as of today,  million boosters and third vaccines had been administered in Scotland.. Number of new cases holding at a concerningly high levelTheres a risk that the spread of the virus could surge againthe past pattern is anything to go by, according to John Swinney.He expressed concern that Covid case rates could rise in coming weeks due to Christmas mingling indoors and with loved ones as the weather gets colder and the festive period nearer.. Cannot rule out "strengthening baseline" measures currently in placeHe confirmed that the government was considering whether to extend the Covid certication scheme to indoor hospitality venues and other areas..removeHowever, the deputy first minister added that no decisions on this have yet been made.. Review of baseline measures will take place a week todayThe three weekly review of the measures currently in place will take place a week today, and John Swinney said they could not rule out reintroducing or strengthening measures.The deputy first minister also took the opportunity to urge people to stick to current guidelines, as well as getting vaccinated and taking regular lateral flow tests.. Covid cases at COP around .%As of November , Covid positivity at COP based on lateral flow tests upon entry to the blue zone was around .%.He acknowledged however we are only just past the halfway point of the conference and confirmed another update would be given following the end of the summit.

title: galashiels-christmas-tree-height-revealed-meeting
story: THE Christmas tree in Galashiels will be shorter than usual this year, a meeting has heard.Galashiels representative Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that Scottish Borders Council was unable to source a ft tree for the town.At a meeting of the community council, Mr Jardine said: ldquoThe Christmas tree is to be delivered and put in place within the next two weeks.:Coronavirus: NHS Borders issues warning amid lsquorisingrsquo number of cases in regionldquoUnfortunately itrsquos not going to be ft, itrsquos going to be ft.ldquoI know some people wonrsquot be happy with that but unfortunately they just couldnrsquot source one.It will be the third consecutive year that a ft Christmas tree will stand in Galashiels.There will be no improvement to the lights in Galashiels this year, or an official switch-on.

title: borders-projects-secure-funding-worth-1-3m-uk-government
story: EIGHT projects across the Borders have secured funding totalling pound. million.Scottish Borders Councilidentied  applications ndash with five unsuccessful and one bid pending a decision.The projects granted funding must be delivered by a deadline of June , .They are:pound, to support the development of environmentally focused courses in entrepreneurship and carbon literacy at Borders Collegepound, to fund an employment and wellbeing programme for people living in housing associations. The Berwickshire Housing programme will deliver digital skills, financial literacy, and promote good mental healthpound, to develop the electric vehicle charging infrastructurepound, for the Scottish Borders Community Development Companyfor workshops to help communities deliver larger scale projectspound, to help the development of a mountain biking centre in Tweeddalepound, for a feasibility study to develop an area of land purchased by Newcastleton and District Community Trustpound, to help support the delivery of training and heritage focused activities by Archaeology Scotlandpound, for the Southern Uplands Partnership to develop energy efficiency training schemesThe money is part of a pound million UK Government funding pot ldquodesigned to support communities to pilot new ideas and approaches to better support people in need.SBC was asked for information about the unsuccessful bids and the project waiting on a decision, but did not supply any details before this newspaper went to press.Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoLarge scale projects that are driven by people who live in our communities and are passionate about making the Scottish Borders a better place to live and work can make a real dference to the lives of many.ldquoThe support provided by the UK Governmentrsquos Community Renewal Fund is vital to helping innovative and locally-led projects breathe new le into towns and villages across the Borders and help support the regions recovery from COVID-..removeThe Conservative Tweeddale East councillor added: ldquoWhilst it is great news that eight projects have been successful in securing funding, we will be working closely with those unsuccessful applicants to identy alternative means of taking forward their projects.Conservative Mid Berwickshire councillor Mark Rowley, SBCrsquos executive member for economic regeneration and finance, described the money as a ldquomajor boost to our region.ldquoThe amount of money granted to these inidual projects reflects the strength of their applications and their potential to improve the lives of Borderers by delivering jobs and improving local communities.ldquoItrsquos welcome news to see the timescale for delivery of these projects being extended after a delay to the announcement of funding. This will give much needed additional time to allow our projects to be delivered to their full potential and provide maximum benefit to the Scottish Borders.

title: borders-buses-remembrance-day-closure-affect-services
story: BORDERS Buses has warned passengers that a number of services will be affected by a ldquoRemembrance Day closure.Berwickrsquos Castlegate will be shut between .am and pm for the Festival of Remembrance, according to the travel company.Borders Buses has issued an apology to impacted customers, adding that it is ldquoout of our control.The services set to be affected are:The am from Galashiels will terminate at Berwick Railway StationThe .am from Tweedmouth Retail Park will start from Berwick Railway Station at .amThe .am service from Kelso to Berwick will be unable to serve Golden Square and will ert from the Catholic school to Berwick Railway StationBThe B will ert via Castle Terrace, A, A to the Catholic school. title: half-price-tickets-now-available-see-tapestry
story: THE GREAT Tapestry of Scotland has been awarded Visit Scotlandrsquos Days Out Incentive Fund.The Tapestry tells the inspirational true story of the countryrsquos history, heritage and culture . It was hand stitched by over  people in communities across Scotland and transported by land, sea and air to come together.It is made up of   and  miles of wool .The visitor centre in Galashiels will now be offering half price day tickets from Monday  November  until  February .During this special offer adult tickets will be pound., concession tickets pound., child ticket pound., Burns family ticket  tickets at pound per ticket, Inglis family ticket  tickets at pound. per ticket.Half-price tickets can be purchased online at: www.greattapestryofscotland or in the centre from Monday  November.

title: borders-activists-mark-cop26-weekend-events
story: ALTHOUGH a great number of activists flocked to COP in Glasgow this weekend, environmentalists in the Borders also shone a spotlight on climate issues here.Supporters of the Fridays For Future campaign joined the weekly silent vigil in Melrose in solidarity with the Fridays For Future march which took place in Glasgow, led by Greta Thunberg.As well as the silent vigil, climate activists in the Borders also took part in a series of events over the weekend, including the Great Borders River Clean and the Borders Book Festival.ldquoTheyrsquore all lsquoclimate beaconsrsquo showing we care for the future of the planet, said Greener Melrose chairman Donald McPhillimy of the weekendrsquos events.ldquoWe feel itrsquos good to celebrate this, while COP is happening, so wersquove launched an appeal for groups, organisations, businesses, organic producers etc in the Borders to send us details about their green activities, and how others can get involved.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedOn Saturday, Greener Melrose met with cyclists who had been loaned Ebikes as part of Ebikes for Borderers ndash a scheme to help people seethey would be a suitable replacement to their car for work or leisure purposes.And over the course of the weekend volunteers across the region joined the Great Borders River Clean, helping to collect rubbish and debris from river banks.Volunteers from Greener Melrose were also at the Borders Book Festival recently with a display of their activities and promoting their map of eco-friendly actions being taken around the Borders. This tied in with talks at the festival from Tom Heap who discussed his new book  Ways to Save the Planet and a presentation from journalist Robert Peston about his experiences at COP.A lsquoGreen Beacons of Hopersquo list is being produced in the Borders to highlight what actions are being taken locally to help tackle the climate crisis, to highlight the green activities people can join in with..removeMr McPhillimy said: ldquoJoining with others, to do something positive, is a great start to helping communities be resilient to the effects of climate change, and it feels good to be working with nature, helping restore decades of damage. It certainly beats feeling anxious and helpless in the midst of all the dire warnings wersquore no longer able to ignore. The first step can be to check out whatrsquos already happening.:Services to be affected by lsquoRemembrance Day closurersquo, says Borders BusesGreen activities being included range from growing your own fruits and vegetables to upcycling old clothes and household items.For more information about Greener Melrose activities, the green map and Beacons of Hope listing, contact greenermelrose@live

title: updated-book-commemoration-remembers-gala-woman
story: THE ONLY woman from Galashiels who died during active service in World War II was remembered recently with the publication of the revised edition of the townrsquos Book of Commemoration.Fay T. Currie, an aircraftwomen nd class, WAAF, was only  years old when she lost her le on the th September , following an illness while serving her country. She passed away at Bridge of Larne and is interred at Galashiels Eastlands Cemetery.Gordon Keddie, a volunteer researcher said: ldquoOur group felt it was important those who lost their lives in WWII should be remembered in the same way as was done with those from WWI in , when the book was published.The Book of Commemoration, which lists the iniduals from the town who gave their lives in both World Wars, was produced by Energise Galashiels Trust and has been updated recently following a yearlong project when a group of volunteers researched each of the  men and one woman fallen from World War II, including poignant photos of the townsfolk.The Book of Commemoration is a legacy to Gala Remembers, the extensive programme of activities that took place in  to commemorate the th anniversary of the end of World War I.Debbie Paterson, EGT committee member, added: ldquoWhile the work of Energise Galashiels Trust is often future-focused, it is important that we reflect back in time too, especially when remembering the people of the town who made the ultimate sacrice by giving their lives to ensure we today enjoy our freedoms. We are honoured to be able to continue to support the Book of Commemoration this year with the addition of more detail and images of the WWII fallen.Energise Galashiels Trust would like to thank Jenner McLaughlin, Hazel Hunter, Tommy Turnbull, and Gordon Keddie for their tireless work that resulted in the comprehensive revision of the Book.

title: galashiels-20mph-speed-limit-set-reversed-roads
story: THE mph speed limit on some Galashiels roads will be removed, a councillor has revealed.Scottish Borders Council introduced the controversial restrictions in October  as part of a trial under its Spaces for People scheme.At a meeting of the community council on Wednesday , Galashiels representative Harry Scott announced that some ldquorevisions are set to go ahead.ldquoTherersquos been some criticism and some love of them [the limits] but the plan at the moment is for a revision, the independent councillor said.:Gala remembers only woman from town to die on active service in WWAccording to Mr Scott, the mph limit will be reinstated ldquoon the road leading to the recycling centre past Melrose Gait and Coopersknowe.A ldquobuffer zone of mph will also be placed from the town boundary on Melrose Road to near the junction with Hawthorn Road, with new mph signage to be erected from that point to indicate the change in limit.Winston Road will also have its mph limit reinstated down to the roundabout with Galafoot, says Mr Scott.He confirmed that the mph limit will stay on Wood Street, as well as on ldquoall the residential schemes in the town.Member of the public Richard Lees said that ldquoa lot of people have universal disapproval of these mph limits on social media, and asked Mr Scottthe council has a way of measuring the advantages of the scheme.:Borders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsResponding, Mr Scott said: ldquoIrsquom not an expert but I do knowa child is struck at mph they have got a  per cent more chance of surviving thantheyrsquore struck at mph.ldquoThere have been some concerns about an increase in pollution but Irsquom reliably told that a car travelling at mph in the proper gear exerts less pollution than one travelling at mph.ldquoMy information is that the mph limit is overall a good thing. I do share with you some reservations about whether mph is really a requirement for a lsquothrough roadrsquo in a town but I think what is being proposed by the officer is reasonable and I certainly donrsquot have any objection to it..removeThe mph speed restrictions are part of an -month council trial covering  towns and villages in the Borders.The aim of the scheme is to make it easier for people to safely walk and cycle during everyday journeys.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedChanges to the restrictions were also announced at a meeting of Selkirk Community Council meeting on Monday .On the A into Selkirk from Galashiels the mph is to be reinstated up to Viewfield Park, then mph through the town thereafter.A mph limit on the A from Hawick will also be reinstated ndash however police and road safety officers have yet to decide where.

title: westruther-woman-admits-drink-driving-offence-weekend
story: A BORDERS woman appeared from custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court on Monday and admitted a drink-driving offence at the weekend while already disqualied.Fty-one-year-old Joyce Barrett, of Westruther, also pleaded guilty to having no insurance.Sentence was deferred until next month for the production of background reports and she was released on bail.You might also be interested in:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsBorders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsDog fouling in the Borders is getting worse and worse, says Gala councillor

title: 3-000-half-price-tickets-available-abbotsford-house
story: VISITORS can explore Sir Walter Scotts beautul Scottish Borders home at Abbotsford for half price thanks to a limited offer as part of the Visit Scotlands Great Days Out in Scotland scheme.There are nearly , half-price tickets to claim, and the offer includes entry to the House, Chapel and Gardens.It also includes half price entry to Christmas  in the historic house, which opens on December th.This magical Christmas experience will allow visitors to explore the house as it might have been for Christmas in Scotts day including a special edition Christmas audio guide.Giles Ingram, Abbotsfordrsquos Chief Executive said: ldquoLast year we extended the season for the first time in seven years, and wersquove decided to do the same again in Scottrsquos th anniversary year, making the event even bigger and better!ldquoWersquore delighted that for the first time ever Father Christmas will be on site to meet local children and our Christmas Market will now be over two weekends in November. The historic house will be open for longer, decorated for the celebrations and telling the story of a special festive season for Scott, when he celebrated the completion of his wonderful home.ldquoAlthough  hasnrsquot been as dficult as , we have missed our international and group visits, which were an important part of our income. Thankfully we have continued to welcome visitors from across the UK and our local market has been very supportive, especially helping us to celebrate Scottrsquos th birthday at Scottfest  in August. Wersquore now inviting them to come again and celebrate a very special Christmas with us.The celebrations at Abbotsford begin with a Christmas Market over the last two weekends in November, featuring local crafters and suppliers. The Markets will run from .am ndash pmon Saturday and Sunday, th  st and th  th November. Christmas wreath making workshops are running on Friday th November..removeThe historic house will close as usual on Tuesday November th and then re-open on Saturday th December, beautully decorated with foliage from the estate and with a unique literary inspired Christmas tree in Scottrsquos magnicent Library.Also on Saturday th December, Father Christmas will arrive at Abbotsford for the first time. Local children can meet him and his Elves in his festive grotto every Friday, Saturday and Sunday until th December.A Christmas shopping evening will be held in the Abbotsford gt shop on Thursday nd December where visitors can find unique presents, including a range of exclusive items created to celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott, including Abbotsford gin  whisky.Ochiltreersquos cafeacute will also remain open throughout December for visitors to enjoy their Christmas menu and festive treats. The gt shop and cafeacute are open seven days a week, am-pm, until rd December and am-pm on Christmas Eve. They are also open thndash th Dec, am-pm, and st Dec, am-pm.Visitors should check the opening dates and times before visiting.Full details of dates, times and tickets for events are on Abbotsfordrsquos web site: scottsabbotsford
