story: Youngsters from the Kintyre-Campbeltown team joined players from Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt, with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the micro P-Ps to the P-s.Conditions were damp underfoot, given the amount of rain that has been falling lately.But the rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone revelling in rolling about in the mud.#Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions,# said a spokesperson. #They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.#It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.#A big game of girls# touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week.This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P, all the way through to the Ps.The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .

title: pupils u15s defeated by top of the league team
story: Campbeltown Pupils shosted top-of-the-league Clyde Community s last Sunday, in their first home game in ision one.The Kintyre side has been working hard on the fundamentals of football and managing to hit the mark.Both teams started the game very strong and it was a great first-half from the local side, with the scoreline level at - when the half-time whistle blew.The travelling Clyde side found their feet very quickly in the second half and held a strong back four which the Campbeltown side could not penetrate.With the visitors# scoring three further goals, the final score was Campbeltown Pupils , Clyde Community .

title: spooky sporting activities
story: Participants of both sports dressed up as they took part in activities last Sunday, on October , All Hallows# Eve itself.Paddleboarders dressed up as witches, a cowgirl, Ghostface and sported spooky head boppers as they enjoyed a ride on Campbeltown Loch.And young golfers donned their glow-in-the-dark gear as they took part in an evening competition at Machrihanish Golf Club before changing into their own frightening costumes for a party in the clubhouse afterwards.

title: helping to preserve kintyres coach heritage
story: As well as penning a commemorative piece to mark the th anniversary of the founding of West Coast Motors, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff is keeping Kintyre#s coach history alive by preserving one of the company#s vintage vehicles.Lawrence, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, was the author of a three-part commemorate article which featured in the Courier over the last three weeks.It formed the basis for several displays that Lawrence took, along with a newly retired West Coast Motors service coach that he and a friend purchased for preservation just before lockdown, to the Glasgow Vintage Vehicle Trust#s annual open weekend on Saturday October  and Sunday October .Despite Covid restrictions, the newly preserved DAF coach made its maiden show appearance in Dunfermline in August.The information on Campbeltown-based West Coast Motors# history was mounted on to four boards, one featuring an introduction, one covering from the s to , another from  to , and the final board bringing the story to around .They were joined by several other boards concentrated on West Coast Motors# Argyll operations, covering Cowal, Bute, Oban and Mull, what could be called the company#s homeland.

title: leader november 5 2021
story: It can be a bit overwhelming when we are told climate change is #the greatest threat to our existence in our short history on this planet# and that humanity is facing #code red#.As the world#s biggest powers debate the best ways to combat the climate challenges we all face, it would be easy to give up in the belief our inidual actions will have little or no impact on the bigger picture.But the cumulative impact of everyone making a few small changes could have a huge  dference.We don#t all have to rush to buy an electric car – how about buying a reusable cup for your coffee instead of using a disposable plastic cup every day, or turning off lights when leaving a room to help save energy Every little helps.Well done to Beinn an Tuirc Distillers for winning two awards at the Scottish Gin Awards.It is worth noting the distillery#s prizewinning spirits are sustainably produced using the company#s own renewable energy from its small hydro-electric scheme.That means those of us in Kintyre can enjoy a guilt-free tipple as we ponder the challenges of climate change, knowing the gin is produced in an environmentally sustainable way, with low delivery mileage!

title: letters november 5 2021
story: The SNP government#s refusal to heed recommendations from CalMac on how many new ferries the operator required to service its routes has led directly to the crisis that has overtaken Scotland#s ferry service.No fewer than  of CalMac#s  active vessels are now more than  years old, which is the recommended operational lespan of a ferry.A debate on the on-going ferry crisis took place this week at the Scottish Parliament.It was very telling that those SNP members who took part in the debate were quite unable, or unwilling, to launch a defence of their own government#s record when it comes to the crisis affecting our ferry service.They know, as we all do, that SNP ministers have failed in their duty of care to our island communities and that excuses will no longer cut it.Nicola Sturgeon now needs to admit her government#s -year failure to protect our leline ferry service, and then actually do something about it, and quickly.I am appealing for used postage stamps which help me raise funds which I then donate to the Guide Dogs for the Blind.Recycling used postage stamps is such an easy way to raise money for the charity and I am always in need of all types of postage stamps, including British, foreign and Christmas stamps.If you are able to help I would be gratefulyou could cut the stamps from their envelopes, leaving approximately cm margin around the stamp, and send them to: Myrna Chave, PO Box , Virginia Water, Surrey, GU ARThank you to everyone who has donated in the past, your assistance in helping me to support this very worthy cause is greatly appreciated.My email address is stampsgdftb@live for more information.

title: thought for the week november 5 2021
story: There are two kinds of silence.There is the kind that numbs and kills, the kind Simon and Garfunkel sang about.It is the silence imposed upon people – that refuses to hear the cry of the hurt, the wounded, the lonely, the unemployed, the hungry, the vulnerable.Veteransfrom wars, and the daily papers strike glorious attitudes. Suffering from unspeakable trauma, they retreat into silence.Breadwinners lose their jobs, and are condemned to poverty, loss of home, reliance on food banks, endless indignity.Young people struggle with mental illness earth and sea, animal and insect le, struggle beneath the load of pollution – and are met with silence.That silence, the silence of the neon god, breeds lies – lies that threaten our planet, our lives and our souls.But there is a dferent kind of silence: a kindly, warm, nurturing silence.It is the silence of the rich humus of mother earth. It is the amniotic fluid bathing our souls for healing. It is out of that silence alone # the Spirit#s silence # that truth springs, and with truth, justice. And with justice, peace, and the healing touch of love.COP is upon us. Amid all the noisy voices, which kind of silence will we choose  Which kind of silence will we permit  Complicity, or graciousness Mercy and peace have met together,

title: a week of celebrations for argyll booklovers
story: Celebrating its tenth anniversary, Book Week Scotland  will include hundreds of online and in-person events.Supported by Creative Scotland and the Scottish Library and Information Council, the week of events themed around #celebration# will run next week, from November  to .To join in the celebrations, leisure trust liveArgyll will be hosting a series of events across its libraries in Argyll and Bute.Pop into Campbeltown Library for a cuppa and a chat during the library open morning on Saturday November .You will be able to find out what is going on in your local library, from Bookbug to after school clubs, local studies enquiries, the online library BorrowBox and much more.Enjoy a game of Jenga or Connect  with your friends or take part in the Bookbug treasure hunt and seeyou can win yourself a mini Bookbug doll.Running from am to .pm, the event is open to all and is free, just like a library membership.Some of Argyll#s other libraries will welcome Scottish authors in celebration of Book Week.On Tuesday November  from pm to pm, Dunoon Library will host Lin Anderson, author of The Killing Tide: Dark Water, Darker Deeds.And in Oban and Rothesay, booklovers are invited to spend an evening with Scottish crime writing author Alex Gray where she will take them on her writing journey so far, including her newest title Before the Storm.The Oban event will be held at the Studio Theatre at Corran Halls on Wednesday November  and the Rothesay event will be at the Moat Centre on Friday November , both from pm to pm.Helensburgh residents are advised not to miss out on a night of thrills, spills and kills as the town#s library presents An Evening with Chris Brookmyre, who has established himself as one of the UK#s leading crime novelists.This will be held at Helensburgh#s Victoria Halls on Thursday November  from pm to pm.liveArgyll will also be launching its inaugural writing competition for young people during the week of celebrations.All secondary school aged young people in Argyll and Bute are invited to take part, writing a story about Argyll folklore.Visit liveargyll liveargyll-libraries-writing-competition for more information including details on how to enter.

title: pupils prove a point in spirited draw
story: Report by Michael McKinlay in KilsythCampbeltown Pupils showed plenty of guts amidst the gusts last Saturday as theyThe McFadyens-sponsored Pupils won the coin toss and opted to go with the strongThe visitors’ defence worked well to deny any clear opportunities for Kilsyth, while an impressive volleyed effort from Ryan Deans at the edge of the box in the early stages flew over the bar by a few inches.The Kintyre Park side’s goal arrived through a good spell of pressure and possession,His looping cross from deep into six-yard box allowed midfielder Deans to outmuscle a Kilsyth defender and force the ball home.Kilsyth#s equaliser came through a thwarted Pupils counter attack.The Kilsyth midfield quickly sent the ball out to their right winger who found considerable time and space to send a low cross into the box.The hosts’ striker moved well to find himself free and direct the ball into the net from close range.The Feathers-Inn sponsored Pupils made it - when Kilsyth, always keen to play outThe Pupils doubled their advantage before the half-time interval when a set piece fromA defender tripped the Pupils man after he cleverly feinted onto his right side to try create space to shoot.Central defender Ross Souden stepped up and opted to go low to the keeper’s right, only to be denied by the post, possibly with a touch from the goalkeeper, but young striker Conner McMurchy, making his first start for the Pupils, reacted well to pounce on the rebound and finished centrally beyond the recovering keeper, despite his best efforts.Into the second half, Kilsyth came out desperate to reduce the deficit now with wind atThe Pupils were forced into a th -minute substitution with Stuart Crossan, operating well in holding midfield, suffering after a knock in the latter stages of the first half, seeing the welcomeof the Pupils’ versatile left-footer Fraser Wylie.This was followed by the introduction of young Calum Ellis, who replaced McMurchy and continued the visitors’ high work rate up front.Kilsyth pulled a goal back after a sustained period of pressure, a pass from deepA well-timed run from a Kilsyth striker put him one-on-one with keeper Alasdair Ferguson # who was otherwise rarely tested due to an impressive collective work rate off the ball from the Pupils – and the striker slotted home clinically to make it -.The hosts secured an equaliser in the th minute, after a set piece was headed clear, and a home midfielder picked up the loose ball with considerable space to thunder a half volley through the pack of Pupils defenders and straight into the bottom left-hand corner.Pressure continued from the hosts in search of a winner but the Pupils coped well toOne notable goalmouth scramble near end of regulation time was cleared off the Pupils# goal line following good awareness from Liam Renton.A couple of late free kick attempts from Kilsyth failed to trouble Ferguson in goal, who showed good concentration to hold onto one final headed effort before the full time whistle, to end Kilsyth#s  per cent home record.It was an impressive feat for the Pupils, who counted seven teenagers in their -strong squad.Tomorrowthe Pupils are at home to BSC Glasgow, who have been inKick off is pm at Kintyre Park. For more information, find @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.The Pupils would also like to thank everyone who entered the club’s Last Person

title: a week of celebrations for argyll booklovers 2
story: The event is part of a larger programme offered by LiveArgyll across its libraries in Argyll and Bute.Local literature lovers are invited to pop into Campbeltown Library for a cuppa and a chat during the open day. There will be an opportunity to find out what is going on in your local library, from Bookbug to after school clubs, local studies enquiries, the online library BorrowBox and so much more.Visitors can also enjoy a game of Jenga or Connect  with their friends or take part in the Bookbug treasure hunt and seethey can win themselves a mini Bookbug doll.The open morning runs from am-.pm on Saturday November , is open to all and is free – just like a library membership.Book Week Scotland  will include hundreds of online and in-person events. Supported by Creative Scotland and the Scottish Library and Information Council, the week themed around ‘Celebration’ will run from November –.To join in the celebrations,  Find out more at liveargyll book-week-scotland-.All secondary school aged young people in Argyll and Bute are invited to take part,

title: driving ambition sees youngsters excel in dalriada
story: Mini rugby players from the Kintyre area have hit the ground running during the first half of the   season with a renewed drive from players and coaches alike.Campbeltown Junior Rugby Club took a hit last season not only on the playing field but off the pitch as well with the loss of #Mr Rugby# John Forster.Due to Covid the club weren’t able to play any fixtures and were only allowed to train.At the beginning of this season there was a lot of optimism after having a successful Summer Camp with membership increasing from the previous season.Players and coaches worked hard in training which has been showing in their development from P right through to S level.There was a lot of excitement around the club with the Dalriada tournaments for P-P starting back up. The squads have now completed three rounds with great success with the P #s impressing on their competitive debut.Kicking things off back in September was the Mid Argyll tournament held at the Ropeworks park in Lochgilphead where there were some excellent inidual and team performances from both age groups.In their first experience of a Dalriada the P s equipped themselves very well beating Oban five tries to one and Etive Vikings -.A hard fought game against Mid Argyll saw the Campbeltown Kintyre team narrowly defeatedleaving them a close second in the overall standings.The P s worked hard as a team and this showed in their performances beating ObanIn an entertaining game against the Etive Vikings a last gasp score by the latter meant a - defeat but the Campbeltown outfit took the overall honours and the club#s first ever Dalriada win.The Oban Dalriada was next and after the performances at Mid Argyll confidence was high in both teams.The P s started off well with an excellent team performance to beat Oban -.Mid Argyll were up next and the team were determined to overturn the defeat at the previous tournament and after a hard fought game ran out - winners.The team bounced back in the next two games to beat a mixed Etive Vikings Mull team - and Mull -. Overall they were pipped to the post by Mid Argyll again finishing in second place.Following their previous success the P  team were ready a raring to go and faced their hosts, Oban s in their opener.After a tough game with big tackles and excellent tries from both teams Campbeltown Kintyre ran - victors. Oban s were next and with little break between games another excellent team performance led to a - win.Next up was a mixed Lochaber and Mull team and some well worked tries led to a - win.In the final game against a mixed Etive Vikings and Mid Argyll team tiredness start to show with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes resulting in a - defeat.Overall Campbeltown Kintyre ran out joint leaders with Oban s.In the most recent Dalriada in Taynuilton Saturday on October  the P s had Mid Argyll in their sights after being beat by their near neighbours twice previously.They didn#t have long to wait for their revenge match as the Lochgilphead-based squad were first up and some great tackles and outstanding inidual efforts saw Campeltown Kintyre get their wish with a - victory.Wins over Mulland Etive Vikingsfollowed and, after falling behind early on, the team fought back for a - draw against Oban.This only left Lochaber and after starting well they never looked back. A - completed their unbeaten run and saw the Campbeltown Kintyre youngsters finish top of the table for the first time.Determined to match their younger clubmates the P  team were equally keen and played some confident rugby to win their matches against Mid Argyll , Etive Vikings , Obanand Oban Sharks .This left a strong Lochaber side between them and achieving their target. After falling behind in the early stages Campbeltown Kintyre dug deep and brought the game back to three tries a piece and with the end of the game drawing near broke away to score the decisive try to also finish undefeated at the top of the table.Mini#s coach Chris Doxsey said: #It has been a brilliant start to the season and one that the club has been building towards for the last six years.#I am so proud of all the players and delighted to be able to be part of a brilliant coaching team and fantastic club.#Thank you to all the parents who have travelled with their children all over Argyll andThe P  team sit top of the overall table with the P  team second on theirs, two points behind Mid-Argyll, going into the final Dalriada in Lochaber on Sunday, November .Campbeltown Junior Rugby Club have opened training up from P through to S and are hoping to start a pre-school club at some point in the future. Anyone interested should contact the club through the Facebook page.

title: kintyre and gigha primaries collaborate for new arts festival
story: Led entirely by pupils, the festival will be held on Gigha in May  with the island#s pupils joining forces with children from Clachan, Achahoish, Rhunahaorine and Glenbarr primaries.The children will work in partnership with specialist artists and performers in the run up to the main event learning skills in a iety of creative arts, including performance poetry and stand-up comedy.Argyll and Bute Council’s policy lead for education Councillor Yvonne McNeilly said: #This sounds like a wonderful, fun project that will challenge and empower pupils, and will give them a great sense of achievement.#Creative arts are renowned for boosting confidence, and helping the social, cognitive and emotional development of young people.#They stimulate the imagination and provide a centre stage for pupils to express themselves.#We are committed to ensuring the positive health and wellbeing of our children and young people in Argyll and Bute and creative arts are a tremendous way of doing this.#I can’t wait to see what plans the children have and seeing them come to fruition in May.#

title: campbeltown at forefront of new climate action project
story: The Scottish government aims to achieve a balance by  between the greenhouse gases put into the atmosphere and those taken out, and has this week nominated seven towns to spearhead that transition.Campbeltown is included in the Climate Action Towns programme which will offer support to the community to find ways of making changes in and around the town to tackle the climate crisis.Findings from this project will then be used to outline learning for climate action that can then be applied across Scotland and beyond.A spokesperson for the government said: #The programme will empower communities to come together and engage in collective climate action, taking account of the unique challenges and opportunities each town faces.#That might include looking at what action can be taken on switching to more sustainable food or renewable energy.#The programme is to be delivered by design agency Architecture and Design Scotland, with funding of £, from the Scottish Government.Councillor Robin Currie, policy lead for the economy and rural growth,said: #It’s great news that Campbeltown has been chosen to become one of Scotland’s first Climate Action Towns.#We continue to work alongside our partners to help Argyll and Bute become the UK’s first Net Zero region.#Climate Action Towns can help lead the way for other towns and communities. Working together, we can make a huge dference.#The six other towns chosen are: Alness, Highlands Annan, Dumfries and Galloway Blackburn, West Lothian Holytown, North Lanarkshire Invergordon, Highlands and Stevenston, North Ayrshire.The announcement came during the Scottish Government’s Just Transition-themed weekend during the UN climate summit in Glasgow .Just Transition Minister Richard Lochhead said: #It is clear that we must decarbonise industry and society in order to mitigate the worst effects of climate change, but we must do so in a way that is fair for everyone and leaves no one behind.#Scotland was at the forefront of the industrial revolution, so we see it as only right that Scotland is at the forefront of this green revolution.#We have a once-in-a-generation opportunity to make changes in a way that will be good for our people, our communities, our economy and our planet – we must seize it.##The Climate Action Towns project aims to support and empower communities to have a say on how their local areas should change as part of a fair and just transition to net zero.#I look forward to seeing how the towns that are taking part rise to the challenge and find ways that will not only make a dference locally but to Scotland and indeed the world.#Architecture and Design Scotland Chief Executive Jim MacDonald added: #For Scotland to adapt to the impacts of climate change, we are all going to need to work together to adapt the ways we live, work, play and move in our cities, towns and villages.#Considering that half of Scotland’s population live in towns, it is vital towns are a key focus in the fight against climate change.#

title: campbeltown author brings his home town to the small screen
story: More than a million copies of Denzil#s DCI Daley novels have sold worldwide and now the rights to the books have been secured to adapt and produce the series for television.#The intention is to film in Kintyre,# Denzil told the Courier. #That#s one of the things I#m most happy about the project.#Every single day people from throughout the world get in touch with me to say they want to visit the area.#Hopefully these dramas will add to this and raise the profile of Campbeltown and beyond.#It#s been great to see the improvements to the town, but there#s been a lot of heartbreak over the years and things haven#t been easy.#The series will be written and directed by leading Scottish playwright and screenwriter Anthony Neilson, most recently acclaimed for his work directing I Hate Suzie.Anthony said: ‘I am privileged to be adapting Denzil Meyrick#s rich and atmospheric DCI Daley books for the screen.#These stories are much more than typical whodunnits and the whole team is committed to delivering a complex, compelling, and accessible series that will stand comparison with the best adult dramas from Europe and the US.#The series is set to star BAFTA-award-winning actor Rory McCann, who viewers will recognise from Game of Thrones.Happy to have his protagonist DCI Jim Daley in such safe hands, Denzil is also confident about another of his favourite characters.#Kintyre, with its extraordinary geography and weather, is one of the biggest characters in the books and I#m really looking forward to seeing it come to le on screen,# he said.#For a writer, it’s been a privilege to showcase the beautul Kintyre peninsula.#Seeing people so invested in this setting, the quirky, authentic, and much-loved cast of characters, must be the goal of anyone putting pen to paper. I’m sure that the television production will take this to the next level.’The series, based on the DCI Daley novels published by Polygon, will be executive produced by Denzil as well as Phil Gilbert and Michael Hallett.

title: district news november 12 2021
story: Three Port Ellen Primary School pupils have been highly commended for their entries in a prestigious photography competition.Katie Harrison, Caillin Swanson and William Campbell were among hundreds of young people aged four to  who entered the Scottish Civic Trust My Place photography competition to document the impact of climate change on their local spaces and places.The prizes were awarded at a digital ceremony on October .The annual competition encourages young people to use photography to explore their local buildings, architecture and archaeology.To tie in with the COP UN climate summit being held in Glasgow, the theme of the  competition is climate change.Katie#s photograph features Port Ellen#s distillery, Caillin#s depicts a rusting electric car charger by a sea wall and William#s is a detailed close-up of corroding metal sandwiched between stone and wood pillars.All entries to the  My Place Photography Competition can also be viewed online at bit.ly MPPCgalleryElizabeth McCrone, a member of the My Place photography competition  judging  and director of heritage at Historic Environment Scotland, said: #Places are important to us in so many ways and it was fascinating to see how our young people view their places through the lens of climate change.#The images powerfully capture the changes in our built and natural environment. The sharing of their observations with us gives real hope for change.#The My Place Photography Competition is supported by Historic Environment Scotland and Jessops and is free to enter and is open to schools, youth groups, clubs and home-educated young people.Visit myplacescotland.org.uk for information on how to enter for the  competition.The owners of two Islay distilleries have moved to help restore precious peatland and water resources to ensure drinks production is sustainable in Scotland.Beam Suntory, the maker of Laphroaig, Bowmore and Teacher#s, and its parent company, Suntory Holdings, have announced the launch of the Peatland Water Sanctuary initiative, a large-scale series of peatland restoration and watershed conservation projects.The companies plan to invest more than £ million in the restoration and conservation of , hectares of peatlands by , enough to produce the same amount of peat that Beam Suntory harvests every year in making its Scotch whiskies on an ongoing basis.Once restored and conserved, peatland naturally accumulates by mm per year, and that mm growth spread across , hectares will equate to Beam Suntory’s annual use.The first project is due to begin at Ardmore distillery in November , followed by subsequent projects at Bowmore and Laphroaig, and other distilleries across Scotland.In the first phase, nearly  hectares of peatland in the Ardmore Knockandy Hill north side slope will be restored, with more to follow in . Restoration will also potentially include Malsach Burn Valley as early as .This initial restoration project at Ardmore will be undertaken in partnership with the James Hutton Institute, which is assisting with the research, planning, and execution of the restoration, and Forestry and Land Scotland, which owns the land.

title: from kintyre to columbia art project shows global solidarity
story: Jan Nimmo has created the Rivers in Solidarity project to highlight the environmental crisis devastating communities living alongside a polluted Columbian river.The river Atrato is fought over by armed guerrillas, illegal gold-miners and paramilitaries and Jan wants to ensure the plight of the river and its people is known worldwide.Known by its Spanish name, Rios Solidarios, the project is for people from anywhere in the world to create artwork that sends messages of solidarity from their river to the communities of the Atrato river in Chocó, Colombia.In her studio in Kintyre Jan has created a piece of art inspired by Machrihanish Water and is working on a depiction of the Whitehouse Burn, and now she is asking people to join her in celebrating their own waterways.She said: #Through the creation of artworks, the project will forge and strengthen networks of solidarity, centred on an understanding of rivers as the leblood of communities across the globe.#The project aims to raise awareness of the socio-environmental devastation affecting the Atrato and the communities who live there and includes portraits created by Jan of the so-called River s, a group of  people who risk their lives to protect the Atrato.Jan explained the complications her project has faced: #I was supposed to travel to Colombia just as the pandemic broke so have had to make #long distance# works which I have been made possible with the help of Steve Cagan, an American photographer and activist with the help of the partners in Colombia # especially Yesenia Palacios, Diana Canbra and Viviana Gonzéle # I couldn#t have made them without them.#Based at her studio in Whitehouse, Jan is working with Professor Mo Hume and Dr Allan Gillies as artist and affiliate of University of Glasgow where academics have been campaigning for years for the human rights of the communities living alongside the Atrato as well as for legal status for the river itself.The Rios Solidarios will create an online gallery of the artworks and stories from rivers around the world, and there will also be opportunities for the artworks to be exhibited.Artworks, which must be square, can be in any D medium or combination of media including painting, collage, recycled materials, embroidery, prints, photographs or they can even be words or poems simply written on a piece of cardboard, for example.All art works should be emailed to Jan at Jan.Nimmo@gla.ac.uk.. Contributors can also discuss their ideas for the artwork with Jan using this email address.

title: from our files november 12 2021
story: A world first is coming to Kintyre, with the announcement of a new hybrid ferry.When the Gigha ferrymen go home at night, they will have to remember to plug the ferry into the mains, for the Tayinloan to Gigha route will get a new passenger and vehicle roll-on roll-off the ferry, which will incorporate a low-carbon hybrid system of diesel, electric and battery power.The other will go to the CalMac service between Skye and Raasay.This is one of two new ferries which are to be funded by the Scottish Government in a contract worth more than £ million.Clyde shipyard Ferguson#s of Port Glasgow has been awarded the contract, allowing it to create more than  new jobs and keep its  current employees.The ferries will come into operation in , a world first for seagoing passenger and vehicle roll-on roll-off ferries.The technology will be cleaner, quieter and cheaper to operate and maintain than ever before.It will help Scotland to meet ambitious climate change targets and demonstrates the vast economic potential of developing green technology and moving to a low-carbon economy.Richard Dean, managing director at Ferguson#s, said the ships should be able to charge from the national grid overnight, drawing on renewable energy.The two ferries will each accommodate  passengers and  cars or two HGVs with a service speed of nine knots.George Taylor, technical director for Caledonian MacBrayne, who was part of the small ferry project team, behind the plans, said: #The introduction of hybrid power units on the next generation of small ferries is an exciting step in our ongoing efforts to improve the environmental impact of our vessels.#TWENTY-FIVE YEARS AGOArgyll and Bute health officials have confirmed that from this week, Campbeltown Hospital will only deal with emergency deliveries while planned deliveries will take place in Glasgow.Antenatal care will continue to be provided exactly as before, and despite delivering only emergency cases, mothers and babies can stillto hospital for recuperation closer to home.And as for the future of the maternity ward – it is not in doubt.#We retain our firm commitment to a -hours-a-day midwery service and there will be no reduction in beds as a result of the changes in deliveries,# said a trust spokesman.The switching of planned deliveries to Glasgow comes after general practitionersthroughout the Argyll and Clyde Health Board area expressed worries about the safety of births in outlying districts.#Local GPs are anxious that they should have the proper expertise and knowledge to deal with deliveries in the hospitals,# said a health board spokesperson.#They need to keep up their expertise, and to do that with the relatively low number of births is very hard.#The number of births has halved in the past  years with only  babies being born here last year.#If there is an emergency that will be dealt with by the doctors,# the spokesperson added.#What we are talking about here is planned deliveries.#Local GPs made their intentions known in April of this year following professional advice from the Royal College of Obstetricians.Since then they have been advising mums-to-be to deliver their babies in specialist centres such as the Southern General Hospital in Glasgow.FIFTY YEARS AGOA Navy bomb disposal unit raced from Faslane to Carradale on Monday after a Tarbert fishing boat had picked up no fewer than four mines in its nets in Kilbrannan Sound.The vessel reported the matter to Southend Coastguard and the Navy men were alerted.It was later discovered that the mines were of the practice type, but could still explode.The bomb disposal unit discharged the four mines at sea.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOThe annual meeting of the Nursing Society in affiliation with Queen Victoria#s Jubilee Institute for Nurses was held in the Christian Institute on Monday afternoon, Reverend Charles McLean BD presided.The annual report was read by the hon secretary Mrs AH Gardiner.In submitting this the st annual report, the committee congratulate themselves on the increasing support they are receiving in their efforts to alleviate, by the services of a trained nurse, cases of sickness and suffering among the community.The work is carried on most successfully by Nurse Rankin.For some months Nurse Rankin was unfortunately off work, owing to ill-health, and her work was undertaken voluntarily by her sister Nurse M Rankin, in addition to her own work as health visitor.The committee desire to express their gratitude to Nurse M Rankin for the work she undertook and accomplished during her sister#s convalescence.Nurse Rankin ed in June, restored in health, and has since been on duty and performed her work with unfailing sympathy and success.A total of  new cases were nursed during the year from st October, , to st October, .Of these cases,  were medical,  surgical  recovered, three were removed to hospital, and  remain on the books of the society.A total of , visits were paid, and the nurse was on duty , and-a-half hours.The ordinary income from subscriptions, donations and investments, including interest from the Cordiner Endowment, amounts to £.s d and the expenditure to £.s d.An offer from the Argyll Education Authority of £ per annum as salary to the nurse for undertaking the work of following up treatment for school children under the doctor employed by the Education Authority has just been received and the committee hope to be able to accept this offer, provided the work involved can be accomplished without interfering with the district work.The committee again desire to remind the public that Nurse#s services are at the disposal of anybody requiring trained nursing, but that, in the case of people who are able to do so, the services are expected to be acknowledged by a donation, however small, to the funds of the society.Dr JP Brown testies to the usefulness of the Nurse#s services and said he did not know how the doctors would get on without her assistance.[Editor#s note: The NHS was still a long way off the National Health ServiceAct  came into effect on July  .]

title: johns lifetime of service to piping honoured
story: John Wilson was awarded the Balvenie Medal for letime services to piping at the Glenfiddich piping championship held at Blair Castle on October .John said: ‘I feel very privileged and honoured to receive this award because I know that there are other people, like me, within the piping world who put something back into piping to improve playing standards and develop the art, particularly within the younger generation.’Speaking at the award ceremony acclaimed Canadian piper, composer and adjudicator Bob Worrall said: #John#s skills as a consensus builder and communicator, along with a clear vision of how to support the growth and improvement of pipe bands have helped us navigate through some potentially dficult times.#He is truly one of the great communicators, someone you would describe as a people person and, who I like to describe, as the people’s friend.#I think all of us as solo piping or pipe band adjudicators are in awe at how John provides adjudication feedback on a critque sheet. I call him the ‘Master of the Metaphor’.#The winning of this prestigious award comes after John was inducted into the Scottish Traditional Music Hall of Fame two years ago to mark his contribution to performance and teaching.John was originally taught by his father Pipe-Major William Wilson, who also  taught many young players in the Campbeltown area.He started competing at the age of eight and won all juvenile events in Scotland, several times over.At the age of  John began studying piobaireachd under Pipe-Major Donald MacLeod and this relationship lasted  years.When John turned to professional competition at the age of just  he won the Argyllshire Gathering medal for the senior Strathspey and reel competition.He went on to win the gold medal at the Northern Meetings at his first attempt and  subsequently won almost every major, solo award including the gold medals at Oban and Inverness plus the senior piobaireachd and the former winners’ march, Strathspey and reel events at both meetings.John joined the police in  and became pipe sergeant of the Strathclyde Police Pipe Band during a period of many major championship victories, which included six consecutive world championship wins.  In total he won  world pipe championships with the band.John is now retired from the police and concentrates on teaching at home and abroad.He is also a senior adjudicator for solo piping and he is currently the convener of the Royal Scottish Pipe Band Association adjudication  management board.

title: liveargyll pedal for pudsey
story: On Friday November , at Victoria Hall, Campbeltown, members of the community are being invited to go the distance for charity and test their own indoor cycling fitness by taking a ramp test.Similar to beep tests but on a bike, the Functional Threshold Powerramp test will not only check basic fitness levels but also calculate an FTP score which can then be used to help track progress and motivate participants throughout future workouts.Anyone interested can turn up any time between -.am and am-.pm and donations for Children in Need will be welcomed.Instructors will be on hand to guide and motivate people throughout the test.A special Coach by Colour taster Torque Endurance class will also be held at the hall from .-.pm, in aid of Children in Need. To book contact Aqualibrium on  .

title: musselburgh man shares nostalgic verses about wee toon home
story: A Campbeltown man now living in Musselburgh has shared with the Courier a couple of nostalgic poems he penned about his hometown.Jim McRobert says that although he only lived in Campbeltown for  years, he has always called it home.A fan of writing poetry, he has penned many verses during lockdown, some of which were published at Edinburgh International Book Festival.As well as nostalgic pieces reflecting on his younger years, Jim also writes about current affairs like Covid- and US politics, some of which we have published in the past.This week, both verses relate to nostalgic Wee Toon tales, the first recounting a supernatural encounter local miners had in a Kintyre cave.#In the early s, many of the new men to the town had come to work in the mine and had all moved from the Denny region,# he said.#They had grown up together and often behaved like teenagers. For example, when there was snow and ice on the roads, they made an ice slide on Tomaig Road from almost the top, down to the Meadows Farm, and they would let off fireworks in the street.#Here is another memory which was never mentioned again##Jim#s second verse, about the enjoyment of a walk around Campbeltown, was written in response to a request from some of his Kintyre friends.

title: thought for the week november 12 2021
story: Memory, however, needs prompts, ranging from shopping lists to diary or calendar entries for signicant anniversaries or events.November  or the Sunday nearest, calls us annually as a nation to remember the sacrice and heroism of two terrible world wars and many conflicts since.The purpose of Remembrance, however, is not simply historical but to bring out a sense of thankfulness and gratitude for what was achieved.On May , , the Prime Minister Winston Churchil, announced on the radio at pm that the war in Europe was over. This became known as VE Day.The records of our church show that on VE Day plus two, a service of thanksgiving included a reading of Psalm , which had been printed in full the previous day on the front page of the Daily Record – yes, the Daily Record, which at that time was owned by Kemsley Newspapers.The generation who attended acknowledged the generous response of a gracious God to the national days of prayer, held during the war and attributed deliverance to His watchful care over us as a nation through many dark days.Remembrance also features in the title deeds of the building in which we worship.The founding fathers determined to build a place, primarily for believers to follow the example of the first disciples and to meet on the first day of the week, to call to mind in bread and wine, the self-sacrice of the Lord Jesus on the cross and the blessing for the whole world which would flow from it.

title: whats new at campbeltown picture house 7
story: Wes Anderson’s The French Dispatch is a love letter to journalists set in an outpost of an American magazine in a fictional th-century French city and brings to le a collection of stories published in The French Dispatch. Written and directed by Wes Anderson, the film stars Benicio del Toro, Frances McDormand, Jeffrey Wright, Adrien Brody, Timothée Chalamet, Léa Seydoux, Tilda Swinton, Mathieu Amalric, Lyna Khoudri, Stephan Park, Owen Wilson, and Bill Murray.The Boss Baby: Family Business Now adults, Tim Templetonis a stay-at-home dad for two adorable daughters, while his estranged brother, Ted , is a big-shot CEO. They come together in an unexpected way when they take a magical formula that transforms them into babies for  hours. Joining forces with Tim#s secret-agent daughter, they must go under cover to prevent an evil genius from turning fellow toddlers into monstrous brats.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: former-guides-celebrated-90-years-combined-service
story: Margaret Craigie and Frances Monaghan, from Musselburgh, have both been members of the guild ndash which offers social opportunities and supports Girlguiding ndash for  years, having joined in .They received their badges from Lorraine Dickson, East Lothian County Commissioner, at a presentation at the Fisherrow Centre on South Street where the guild meets. Afterwards, a lsquosilhouettersquo quiz was enjoyed, followed by cake and tea.The Trefoil Guild, which is open to women and men over the age of , also supports Scouting.Members meet with friends, develop interests, tackle new challenges, enjoy outings and holidays together. They help Girlguiding at district, ision, county, region, UK and international level.Margaret Craigie joined the Brownies in Musselburgh in  and went on to become a Guide. She became a Brownie Guider in the rd Musselburgh Brownies in the s.Frances was a Brownie and Guide in Campbeltown. In Musselburgh, she was an adult helper with the th Musselburgh Brownie pack.Frances said that when she moved to Musselburgh after she married, and as a new mum, she found friendship with the guild, which had a membership of nearly  in the s. She also enjoyed helping to arrange outings and Christmas meals over the years.

title: hound-music-causing-stir-gullane
story: Bill Hudson, of Muirfield Steading, adopted Border collie Lottie when his previous pet, Roxy, passed away.And when Lottie proved to be something of a mischief-maker, chewing through his shoes, his work notes and two sets of headphones, Bill decided to harness her energy with the power of music.He told the Courier: ldquoShersquos absolutely running me ragged!ldquoBut I was watching this programme that showed a Border collie that had been trained to get a beer from the fridge.ldquoAnd I thought,I could train a dog to do something like that, shersquod be doing something shersquos born to do ndash be a sheepdog.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppyBut rather than fetch beer, Lottie is being trained to sing the blues.Bill, , explained: ldquoShersquos not quite got the hang of it yet but shersquos getting there, singing at the right times.ldquoShe managed to play a chord on the guitar ndash I was strumming away and she came up and started twanging the strings with her teeth.ldquoAnd I thought, well, thatrsquos not a bad note, actually!ldquoI do recordings at home and Irsquove looped one of her barks, and Irsquom trying to record her, because you can get any sound and then use it.ldquoShersquos got potential.And Lottie is in safe musical hands, as Billrsquos uncle was William Blezard, musical director to Noeumll Coward, Marlene Dietrich and Joyce Grenfell.Bill Hudson and Lottie the puppy.Bill said: ldquoHe also worked with Sir Laurence Olivier, wrote film music for Pinewood, and the music for BBCrsquos Play School, with Johnny Ball and Brian Cant.Bill, a freelance sub editor by day, is himself a musician, playing open mic nights and writing, producing and selling music. He said: ldquoI stream it on Spoty and SoundCloud too. It gets played anywhere from Egypt to Toronto ndash things Irsquod forgotten Irsquod even written!Gullane residents should be on the lookout for a carol-singing Lottie this Christmas!

title: lottery-funding-community-connections-group
story: North Berwick Coastal Community Connections , launched in , was set up to identy those in the community who were experiencing loneliness and social isolation, with a view to befriending them, building their confidence and helping them make connections.Until now funded by North Berwick Trust and East Lothian Councilrsquos One Council Funding, it reaches out to people in Aberlady, Ballencrieff, Dirleton, Drem, Fenton Barns, Gullane, Kingston, North Berwick and Whitekirk.In March , the project had to adapt to the pandemic, with many of its members shielding.Project officer Carol Stobie developed befriending and lsquobuddy walksrsquo services, as gatherings were forced to come to a halt.Robert Burgon, NBCCC co-chair, said: ldquoWe are delighted that the project has received this support and recognition.ldquoThere is possibly even more need than ever for a project of this nature as so many people in our community have experienced the long-lasting impact of the pandemic.ldquoWe look forward to developing our services as we address social isolation and loneliness, across all age groups, in the coastal ward.Carol added: ldquoWersquore absolutely thrilled that funding has been secured.ldquoItrsquos been a tough  months, with many of our members struggling with greater isolation than ever, and new referrals steeply increasing over this time.ldquoNow we can plan to reinstate some of our original core face-to-face work, including Scone Cafe at the Abbey Church Hall, and to reopen our partnership activities with many other community groups.ldquoThis includes a lsquocompassionate neighboursrsquo project to support people with a terminal diagnosis, in partnership with North Berwick Compassionate Communities.ldquoWersquoll also be able to sustain our newer one-to-one services, with befriending and buddy walks for the most vulnerable members.ldquoWersquore hoping to recruit a third team member for administration and communications tasks.To find out more about NBCCC, contact Carol on   or nbc-communityconnections@outlook

title: former-haddington-aldi-store-split-three
story: The supermarket giant moved from its long-standing home off Whittingehame Drive to Haddington Retail Park at the end of September.Now, permission has been given to Ediston Haddington Ltd to make changes to the former supermarket.Plans approved by East Lothian Council show the building being split into three storage and distribution units.Businesses for the units have not been named but each unit will also have a counter for trade and retail sales.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department said it was ldquonot unusual for a storage and distribution unit to operate a retail trade counter, which will make up only a small section of the units. A series of new access points will also be created.Aldi, which was based off Whittingehame Drive for nearly  years, announced it would be moving from the site last year.Now, the supermarket chain is based on the western edge of Haddington, alongside Home Bargains, The Food Warehouse and Costa Coffee.There is a vacant unit on the site, while plans have also been approved for a petrol station.

title: ross-high-school-head-pupils-vow-build-back-covid
story: The coronavirus pandemic saw exams scrapped and pupils learning virtually.With youngsters now back in the classroom, Cameron MacLennan, Ellie McMillan, Sadie Glynn and Anya Martin are looking forward to working together for the next six months to overcome any obstacles.Construction work to extend the Tranent school is also under way while its community bounces back from the coronavirus pandemic.Seventeen-year-old Anya said the mental health of pupils and the recovery from Covid- were both important issues to focus on.The S pupil was one of a number of students to put their name forward for the head pupil role.Each student had to make a video outlining three priorities to focus on over the coming year.An interview then took place before Cameron, Ellie, Sadie and Anya secured their positions.Anya was also keen to build on inclusivity with ASN pupils and was looking forward to the year ahead after a challenging  months.The pupil said: ldquoA lot about school is the social aspect, seeing your friends every day, talking to lots of people and that has not been able to happen.ldquoFor S as a year, the year has been brought together.Anya, who hopes to go on and study medicine, was keen to build on that closeness and ldquomake sure everybody has a good final year.She added: ldquoIt has been hard for everyone in the past few years.ldquoWe want to make sure everybody is enjoying it.The keen hockey player has been involved in a number of dferent aspects of school le and had been keen to be a head pupil in her final year.She said: ldquoThroughout school, I was always involved in a lot of things. I was junior leader and that led me on to becoming a prefect.ldquoIt is always a thing I wanted to do and I have always been quite involved with the school.Paul Reynolds, headteacher at the secondary school, congratulated the four head pupils on their selection.He said: ldquoThese amazing four pupils were chosen after a very rigorous selection process including applications, video presentations, pupil and staff votes, and formal interview.ldquoTo say I am proud of them is an understatement.ldquoAll four have lived and modelled the school values of positivity, respect, integrity and perseverance throughout their entire school career and are wonderful role models to all our pupils here.ldquoThey have grasped the many opportunities available to them throughout their time here at Ross High, including participation in many sports, Duke of Edinburgh, volunteering in the ASN department and much, much more.ldquoIrsquod like to congratulate them and look forward to working with them closely in this lsquoYear of Rebuildrsquo at Ross High School.

title: first-step-project-offer-christmas-essentials-families-need
story: They include Christmas presents for children, childrenrsquos winter clothing, festive food and toiletry essentials.Referral forms are available by emailing projectmanager@firststepmusselburgh, visiting its website at www.firststepmusselburgh or popping into its premises at  Galt Avenue.All forms must be ed by November .First Step is a community project for families with young children, funded by East Lothian Council and other funding bodies.It was set up in  by a group of local parents who wanted somewhere safe and comfortable where they could meet and their children could play.The project has developed its services to meet local needs while continuing to be managed by a community-led management committee and employing a staff team to support local families.

title: details-remembrance-day-parade-confirmed
story: Irene Tait, group chair, said: ldquoWe have taken this decision for safety reasons.ldquoIt was felt to have so many people in a small area, at this present time, would not be advisable.ldquoHowever, this should not deter people from going to the memorial to lay a wreath or cross on the th, th or indeed any time.ldquoThe Remembrance Sunday parade will still go ahead, leaving the Old Town Hall at .am to walk up to St Michaelrsquos Parish Church, Inveresk, where a service of remembrance will be held.ldquoThe parade will leave the war memorial at St Michaelrsquos Church at .pm to walk back to the town hall, where the parade will stand down.

title: compass-schools-generous-harvest-donation-day-centre
story: Children and staff at the townrsquos The Compass School celebrated the annual harvest with a series of class thanksgiving assemblies.Each assembly looked at how harvests were celebrated throughout the world and focused on the importance of sharing with others.The school, on Haddingtonrsquos West Road, made its annual harvest thanksgiving appeal and a huge collection of tins and packets of food was brought into school by children, parents and staff.The gts were then taken to Haddington Day Centre by primary seven children and staff for distribution to the elderly visitors to the centre.The children could only make a short visit to the centre but were able to say hello from a distance to the clients in attendance there, and even sing Happy Birthday to one of the clients celebrating her special day.Mark Becher, headmaster at The Compass, was pleased to see the connection between the school and the day centre continue.He said: ldquoThe children have spent time considering how important the harvest is to people around the world, with festivals often being held to celebrate each countryrsquos harvest, with the time of year when this takes place ying around the globe.ldquoIn every country, sharing what one has with others forms an important part of each harvest celebration.ldquoEach year, the school has a harvest collection and we have been very pleased to make gts of these to the elderly in the community through the day centre in Haddington.ldquoWe have a strong link with the day centre and it is great for the youngest members of the community to be able to have the opportunity to help the older citizens of the town.ldquoWith the day centre being closed to all visitors last year, it was good to be able to say hello to some of the clients on our visit this time and convey our best wishes to them and their fellow clients.

title: opera-east-lothian-ready-sing-live
story: Opera East Lothian last performed at the beginning of  and was devastated when its Easter charity concert and following performances were cancelled due to the coronavirus pandemic.The musical company is now back with an evening of operatic favourites, performing at The Strawberry Barn, Thistly Cross, near West Barns.John Marshall, music director, said: ldquoThe chorus cannot wait to sing to a live audience again.ldquoWe would normally be performing an opera in November to around  people but we are keeping our concert very informal and low key, with safety in mind.ldquoWe are also excited to be at The Strawberry Barn, presenting our concert in a cabaret style for the first time.Opera East Lothian will also host a raffle on the night, with prizes including an NB Gin tour, Sunday lunch at La Potiniegravere in Gullane and a one-night stay at The Plough Inn, Leitholm, in the Scottish Borders.The evening starts at .pm on Saturday .For more information, visit www.operaeastlothian

title: destiny-project-using-football-help-tackle-poverty
story: The Destiny Project, co-ordinated and created by Prestonpans Community Council vice-chairman Andrew Stevenson, provides support and advocacy for children and young people in East Lothian.The Destiny Cup, a five-a-side football tournament open to all organisations in East Lothian and Edinburgh, will start at am on November  at the Pennypit in Prestonpans.The project has partnered with Street Soccer Scotland to send a ldquoclear message that poverty is something that impacts lives within our communities.Andrew said: ldquoTogether we can raise the awareness of mental health and poverty within our communities.ldquoMany thanks to Street Soccer Scotland for the support and encouragement.

title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  DecemberTuesday  DecemberThursday  December

title: council-workers-get-extra-day-off-next-year-queens-platinum-jubilee
story: East Lothian Councilrsquos Labour administration cabinet this week agreed to make Friday, June , a public holiday for all its employees next year.However, while some local authorities are also making Thursday, June , an official holiday, East Lothian workers will not be automatically given the four-day weekend.The UK Government advised councils to move their official May Bank Holiday to Thursday, June , to create the extended holiday.At a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet this week, members were reminded their workers do not get a May Bank Holiday so it cannot be moved to June.Instead, the Labour administration was told staff would beldquoencouraged to take a dayrsquos annual leave to extend the celebrations.Morag Ferguson, head of corporate support, told cabinet: ldquoAs the council does not recognise a fixed May Bank Holiday now, those staff who wish to use one of their annual leave days for the Thursday will be encouraged to do so and managers will be asked to facilitate this where possible.The cabinet agreed to make Friday, June , an extra public holiday for all staff, including teachers, next year.Councillor Jim Goodfellow urged community councils and area partnerships to take the initiative in planning local parties and celebrations across the county.He said: ldquoThis is an event of signicant importance and I am sure there are iniduals and groups within East Lothian who will wish to organise something to mark this day, perhaps with celebrations or street parties.

title: dunbar-schoolgirl-presents-poppy-poem-great-uncles-memory-towns-legion
story: Kirsten Goughrsquos poignant poem, Irsquove Been The Poppy, attracted national interest last year.Youngsters at Dunbar Primary School were studying the Second World War, in which Kirstenrsquos great uncle Cecil Thomas Dundas died.The -year-old was killed when merchant navy ship SS Jumna ndash on which he was rd officer ndash was shelled by the German heavy cruiser Admiral Hipper on Christmas Day .Ahead of this yearrsquos preparations to mark Remembrance Day, Kirsten and her mum Carol were invited to attend a veteransrsquo breakfast meeting organised by Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal Team.The group has delivered collection cans and boxes throughout the town for this yearrsquos commemorations.To mark  years of the poppy, Kirsten recited her poem to the gathered veterans.She also presented a framed copy, specially printed on school letterhead, to Dunbar Legion Poppy Appeal team leader Sharon Kaszuba.The story attracted interest from the John OrsquoGroats Journal, as well as the University of Southampton, which has archives on the RRS Discovery .

title: east-lothian-remembrance-events-2021-details-commemorations-around-county
story: Remembrance services were scaled back last year in the face of the coronavirus pandemic.Various restrictions are still in place but services are being held in a number of towns and villages.Provost John McMillan said he was glad some Remembrance events couldthis year.He added: ldquoIt is really important to remember and people remember in their own inidual ways.While most communitiesrsquo events are on Sunday, the occasion will be marked in West Barns on Saturday. Anyone attending should head to the villagersquos war memorial for .am, with the Rev Brian Hilsley, interim moderator and locum at Belhaven Parish Church, giving a brief address at .am. The wreath-laying will then take place and refreshments will be available in West Barns Village Hall.In Haddington on Sunday, St Maryrsquos Parish Church is holding two services. There will be the usual informal all-age service at .am, and at .am an in-person, ecumenical service of Remembrance. Members of the congregations of other churches in the town will join with invited representatives of community groups.A spokesperson for St Maryrsquos said: ldquoBecause our capacity is much reduced, there will be limits on the number of people who can attend in-person. As it was in , the service will be livestreamed.To book a place, text or call   -am or -pm tomorrow .A wreath-laying takes place at the townrsquos war memorial at .am, while wreaths will also be laid in Athelstaneford and at the Ferguson Memorial in Haddington.In North Berwick, St Andrew Blackadder Church hosts a service at .am on Remembrance Sunday. Participating organisations will hold a parade to the church, led by North Berwick Pipe Band, leaving Imperial car park at about .am. After the service, there will be a parade to the war memorial, where the Act of Remembrance and wreath-laying ceremony will take place at about noon.In Dirleton, Remembrance Day will see the rededication of the villagersquos war memorial, which has been restored . The memorial service starts at .am at the monument, led by the Rev David Graham Sir Hew Dalrymple will also give a short address and music will be provided by Lyle Crawford, a senior member of North Berwick Pipe Band.Aberlady will have a short service at the war memorial at am and people are being asked to assemble at .am. There will be representatives from Territorial Army and Marine Commandos, community organisations, church, community councillors and Scouts. There will then be a service in Aberlady Parish Church at .am, taken by visiting minister the Rev John Gordon.Kaye MacAskill, church treasurer, said: ldquoNumbers are still restricted in church, so wersquore not able to have groups of unormed organisations. Itrsquos a small representative group from each of them. Some members of the public will be able to come into church but we canrsquot have a full church this year.In Gullane, there is an lsquoactiversquo Remembrance at the villagersquos war memorial at am on Sunday. Refreshments are available at The Watchman Hotel afterwards.In Dunbar, tea and coffee will be served at Dunbar Royal British Legion from am. The parade of organisations will make its way from High Street to the townrsquos war memorial on Marine Road at .am before a service is held at am. The organisations then make their way back into the town centre.A short service of remembrance will be held at the war memorials beside Athelstaneford Parish Church and Stenton Parish Church at .am on Sunday.At Prestonkirk Parish Church in East Linton, there will be a joint service for all three churches in the parish ndash Stenton, Athelstaneford and Prestonkirk ndash at .am and then at the war memorial at noon.Meanwhile, in Prestonpans, a Remembrance parade will go ahead as normal, with a socially distanced crowd in attendance. The parade marches off from the Legion at .am along Rope Walk to Redburn Road, North Grange Avenue and down West Loan to the war memorial. An upgrade to the square that surrounds the war monument is under way but space will be made to ensure the ceremony can take place.In Cockenzie and Port Seton, a similar parade takes place on Sunday, leaving the Legion at .am and arriving at the village green for .am. The service will be followed by a two-minute silence at am before parading to Cockenzie Old Parish Church. Following a service at the church, the parade willto the Legion, where at about .pm a salute and silence, followed by a lament from the pipe band, will take place.In Longniddry, a church service takes place at Longniddry Parish Church on Sunday at .am.In Tranent, a parade starts from East Lothian Co-operative Bowling Club, down Ormiston Road, High Street, Church Street, Winton Place and High Street to Tranent Parish Church for a service at .am.In Elphinstone, a parade begins at .pm from Elphinstone Minersrsquo Club to Main Street for a gathering at the war memorial, before ing to the minersrsquo club for .pm.In Ormiston, a remembrance service takes place at the village church at .am, while two wreaths will be laid at the side of the building. Following the service, a walk to the memorial will take place where a further two wreaths will be laid.Pencaitlandrsquos church holds a service at .am, followed by the community act of remembrance at the war memorial at noon.In Musselburgh, there will be no official service on Remembrance Sunday at the Mall Fountain but a parade will leave Musselburgh Town Hall at .am to walk to St Michaelrsquos Church, Inveresk, for a service of Remembrance.In Wallyford, a service takes place at St Clementrsquos Church at am. Wreaths will be laid in the church garden at am.

title: section-a1-closed-overnight-repairs
story: Overnight repairs are being carried out on the eastbound carriageway of the road between Abbotsview Junction and East Linton.BEAR Scotland is carrying out the work from pm to am, with the eastbound section of road closed between those times.Traffic will come off the A at the Abbotsview Junction and follow the A before rejoining the A at Thistly Cross Roundabout.The ersion is expected to add about three minutes to the journey.Tommy Deans, BEAR Scotlandrsquos south east network manager, said: ldquoThese repairs will enhance safety for motorists.

title: coastguard-lifeboat-called-kayakers-get-difficulty-off-cockenzie
story: North Berwick and Dunbarrsquos Coastguard teams received a call shortly before noon and were joined by Kinghornrsquos RNLI volunteers.Just prior to the arrival of the RNLI crew at about .pm, it was confirmed that the two kayakers had made it ashore but one kayak was still drting east.A spokesperson for Kinghorn RNLI said: ldquoWhilst personnel from North Berwick Coastguard Rescue Team and Dunbar Coastguard attended to the paddlers, we tried to recover the kayak.ldquoAt this point, it became apparent that two other members of the group had continued to Longniddry and their welfare was unknown.ldquoThe leboat was tasked to check up on them but it was soon confirmed that they were safely ashore.ldquoWe then ed to locate the kayak, which by now had drted east of Port Seton onto rocks.ldquoA crew member went ashore to assist Coastguard personnel recover the delicate kayak, which had sustained damage and had filled with water. It was successfully emptied and taken to the harbour for collection.

title: appointments-now-needed-east-lothians-vaccine-bus-long-queues-cold
story: The bus, launched by East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnershipas a drop-in service last Tuesday, was attended by more than  people in its first four days of service.It provides Covid- boosters and flu jabs for lsquopriority groupsrsquo, including people aged over  and those who are clinically extremely vulnerable.The bus visited Ormiston Medical Practice on the first two days and Gullane Medical Practice on Thursday and Friday.Photos shared on social media of the bus at its stop in Gullane showed traffic chaos, forcing the police to attend, and some members of the public complained of waits of up to two hours in the cold.A spokesperson for ELHSCP said: ldquoDue to an extremely high level of interest in the service which resulted in long queues, y waiting times and local traffic disruption, ELHSCP has decided to review how the bus operates.ELHSCP will now deliver an outreach programme and the vaccination bus will operate on an appointment referral basis only. Vaccinations will no longer be available on a drop-in basis.The spokesperson added: ldquoOur expectation is that the majority of people living in East Lothian who are eligible will receive their flu and Covid booster vaccinations at one of our clinics in Musselburgh Primary Care Centre or East Lothian Community Hospital in Haddington.ldquoPlease be assured thatyou are over  or clinically extremely vulnerable and have already received your flu vaccination but are now eligible for your Covid booster, you should expect to receive an appointment letter from NHS Lothian in the coming weeks.Members of the public complained on social media of long waits in the cold.One said: ldquoI waited for about one hour and  minutes for my vaccination.ldquoDespite the pressure of numbers, the staff were very efficient and friendly.Another said: ldquoPersonally feel that this could be done in a much safer environment like a golf course or open field away from homes.ldquoRight now, many people who are potentially sick could be spreading the virus [unknowingly] among vulnerable people.Another added: ldquoPeople were standing out in the icy cold wind for hours today, then they sat under a temporary cover attached to the side of the bus to be injected, then sat on chairs in the cold windy shade until they were allowed to leave.The ELHSCP spokesperson said: ldquoIf you are invited to attend an appointment on the vaccination bus, please be aware that:

title: films-screened-tranents-fraser-centre-weekend
story: The trio star in The Last Duel, which focuses on respected knight Jean de Carrouges.When the much-admired squire Jacques Le Gris viciously assaults Carrougesrsquo we, she steps forward to accuse her attacker, an act of bravery and defiance that puts her le in jeopardy.The film, directed by Ridley Scott, is shown at pm with a second screening at the Tranent venue next Thursdayat pm.Meanwhile, therersquos also plenty to entertain youngsters.The Gruffalorsquos Child takes to the big screen todayand Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is shown on Saturday.The Gruffalorsquos Child sees Gruffalorsquos daughter embark on a journey to find the Big Bad Mouse.Ronrsquos Gone Wrong is the story of Barney, a socially awkward middle-schooler, and Ron, his new walking, talking, digitally connected device, which is supposed to be his lsquoBest Friend out of the Boxrsquo.Both films are shown at pm.

title: see-bonnie-babies-couriers-1-000-competition
story: In todays Courier print edition, we feature - for the last time - all the cute kids in the running for the pound first prize.Theyre so sweet that we just had to share them online too!The winner is the little one with the most votes after the final round - and votes can only be cast using the coupon published in this weeks Courier.So pick up a copy today!
